hasDitaContent.@value: Both vemurafenib and amifampridine prolong the QT interval. Most manufacturers advise avoiding the use of two or more drugs that are associated with QT prolongation. Increasing age, female sex, cardiac disease, and some metabolic disturbances (notably hypokalaemia) predispose to QT prolongation.

hasMessage.hasTextContent: Both  vemurafenib  and  vandetanib  prolong the QT interval. Most manufacturers advise avoiding the use of two or more drugs that are associated with QT prolongation. Increasing age, female sex, cardiac disease, and some metabolic disturbances (notably hypokalaemia) predispose to QT prolongation.

Increasing age, female sex, cardiac disease, and some metabolic disturbances (notably hypokalaemia) predispose to QT prolongation.

hasDitaContent.@value: Vemurafenib is predicted to increase the exposure to venetoclax. Manufacturer advises avoid or monitor for toxicity.

hasMessage.hasTextContent: Vemurafenib   is predicted to   increase   the exposure to   venetoclax .  Manufacturer advises avoid or monitor for toxicity .

Increasing age, female sex, cardiac disease, and some metabolic disturbances (notably hypokalaemia) predispose to QT prolongation.

hasDitaContent.@value: Vilanterol is predicted to cause hypokalaemia (potentially increasing the risk of torsade de pointes) when given with vemurafenib. Manufacturer makes no recommendation.

hasMessage.hasTextContent: Vilanterol   is predicted to   cause   hypokalaemia (potentially increasing the risk of torsade de pointes) when given with   vemurafenib .  Manufacturer makes no recommendation .
